text:
Bitcoin mining is a lot like reindeer 
mating. Ok, that analogy is a bit weird,

but it’s won-deer-ful for explaining why Bitcoin 
mining – which is the processing transactions of

the digital currency and creating new Bitcoin 
– uses such a ridiculous amount of energy.

You see, male reindeer compete for mates, and 
the largest male with the largest antlers is most

likely to win the fight and get the girl…girls, 
really, since males usually compete for up to 15

females at a time. Bitcoin-mining computers, too, 
compete. Every 10 minutes, they go head-to-head

in a race to correctly guess the answer to 
a really complicated math equation. The most

powerful computer, capable of making the most 
computations per second, is most likely to win,

earning them the right to mate with all the–I 
mean, the right to confirm a group of Bitcoin

transactions and get some Bitcoin of their own.
So whether you're a male reindeer or a computer

on the Bitcoin network, the more powerful you 
are, the more successful you're likely to be.

But being powerful requires a lot of 
energy. Compared to smaller reindeer,

the biggest males need to consume much more 
food to fuel their massive bodies and grow large

antlers for the mating season. Similarly, compared 
to the most basic Bitcoin mining hardware,

the most powerful Bitcoin-mining operations 
gobble up tens of thousands of times more energy.

And that energy-use is constantly growing because 
just like the competition for dominance among

male reindeer has led to the evolution 
of larger reindeer with larger antlers,

competition is pushing Bitcoin miners to 
use computers that are ever-more powerful

and energy-hungry. The result? An arms race 
resulting in ever-higher energy consumption.

But that doesn't mean energy use will increase 
forever. If energy is hard to come by,

reindeer – and their antlers – can't get all 
that big; that's why reindeer living in places

where food is abundant and easy to find, grow the 
largest bodies and antlers. And if energy is hard

to come by - or too expensive - Bitcoin miners 
must scale back their computer power, which is

why places where energy is reliable and cheap 
attract the most energy-hungry Bitcoin miners.

Over millions of years of evolution, reindeer 
as a species have basically gotten as beefy as

they're likely to get - at least given the 
energy that they currently have available.

But since Bitcoin is still early in its evolution, 
this exponential growth is likely to continue.

Unless, that is, the value of Bitcoin stops 
increasing or how it’s mined fundamentally

changes. Hopefully, it doesn’t take 
millions of years to rein it in.
